elements.content: The compound Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I) could be conveniently converted into the monoanion [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]- (I-1) and the dianion [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]2- (I-2) by treatment with excess NaH and 2 equiv of n-BuLi, respectively. The monoanion I-1 could be further converted into the trianion [Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B10H11)]3- (I-3) by reaction with 2 equiv of Na metal in THF and into the pentaanion [Me2C(C5H4)(arachno-C2B10H11)]5- in the presence of LnCl3 and excess Na metal in THF. Reactions of LnCl3 with the monoanion I-1 in molar ratios of 1:1, 1:2, and 1:3 generated the mono-, bis-, and tris-ligated organolanthanide compounds [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]LnCl2(S)n ((S)n = (THF)3, Ln = Er (1), Sm (2); (S)n = (DME)2, Ln = Nd (3)), [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]2SmCl(THF)2 (4), and [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]3Sm·0.5C7H8 (5), respectively. Reaction of LnCl3 with 1 or 2 equiv of the dianion I-2 gave the same compound, [{η 5:σ-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)}2Ln][Li(DME)3] (Ln = Sm (6), Yb (7)). 6 could also be prepared by treatment of 2 with 1 equiv of the dianion I-2. Reaction of YbI2 with 1 equiv of I-2, followed by treatment with 1 equiv of I-1, also gave compound 7. However, YbI2 reacted with 2 equiv of I-1 to afford the organoytterbium(II) compound [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]2Yb(THF)2 (8). Interaction of SmI2 with 2 equiv of I-1 yielded two compounds, the redox product [η 5:η 6-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Sm(THF)2 (9) and the tris-ligated compound 5. The compound [η 5:η 6-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er(THF)2 (10), an analogue of 9, was prepared by treatment of 1 with 2 equiv of Na metal or by reaction of ErCl3 with 1 equiv of I-3. Treatment of 10 with excess Na metal gave the first organolanthanide compound containing a η 7-carboranyl ligand, [{[η 5:η 7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er}2{Na4(THF)9}] n (11). Its Dy analogue, [{[η 5:η 7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Dy}2{Na4(THF)9}] n (12), could also be prepared by a “one-pot” reaction of DyCl3, I-1, and excess Na metal. Treatment of 11 with 2 equiv of ErCl3 in THF gave the novel tetranuclear cluster [{η 5:η 7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)}Er2(μ-Cl)(THF)3]2 (13), in which the Er3+ ions replace all Na+ ions in 11. All of these compounds were fully characterized by various spectroscopic data and elemental analyses. The solid-state structures of compounds 4−11 and 13 have been confirmed by single-crystal X-ray analyses.

elements.content: A versatile ligand, Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11), can be converted into the monoanion, the dianion, the trianion, and even the pentaanion under proper reaction conditions, which has led to the isolation and structural characterization of a variety of organolanthanide compounds.
elements.clean_text: A versatile ligand, Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11), can be converted into the monoanion, the dianion, the trianion, and even the pentaanion under proper reaction conditions, which has led to the isolation and structural characterization of a variety of organolanthanide compounds.

elements.content: By taking advantage of unique carborane molecules and traditional cyclic π-ligands such as cyclopentadienyl and indenyl as well as bridging ligands, we have designed two types of silicon-bridged versatile ligands, Me2Si(C5H5)(C2B10H11) and Me2Si(C9H7)(C2B10H11), which have led to the isolation and structural characterization of a new class of organolanthanide compounds. Since the Me2Si linkage is susceptible to nucleophilic attack, the carbon-bridged ligand Me2C(C9H7)(C2B10H11) was then recently developed in our laboratory. The results show that both the cyclic organic group and the bridging atom have a large influence on the acidity of the CH proton of the carborane cage in these ligand systems, which in turn affects the reactivity of the resulting organolanthanide compounds. They also indicate that the C−C(carborane) bond can be broken under traditional deboronation conditions such as KOH/MeOH6 presumably due to the electron-withdrawing ability of the indenyl group, leading to the formation of nido-C2B9H12 -.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

By taking advantage of unique carborane molecules and traditional cyclic π-ligands such as cyclopentadienyl and indenyl as well as bridging ligands, we have designed two types of silicon-bridged versatile ligands, Me2Si(C5H5)(C2B10H11) and Me2Si(C9H7)(C2B10H11), which have led to the isolation and structural characterization of a new class of organolanthanide compounds. Since the Me2Si linkage is susceptible to nucleophilic attack, the carbon-bridged ligand Me2C(C9H7)(C2B10H11) was then recently developed in our laboratory. The results show that both the cyclic organic group and the bridging atom have a large influence on the acidity of the CH proton of the carborane cage in these ligand systems, which in turn affects the reactivity of the resulting organolanthanide compounds. They also indicate that the C-C(carborane) bond can be broken under traditional deboronation conditions such as KOH/MeOH6 presumably due to the  electron-withdrawing ability of the indenyl group, leading to the formation of nido-C2B9H12 -.

elements.content: To prepare a bridged trianion ligand bearing both a cyclopentadienyl ring and a dicarbollide group which may offer organometallic compounds with “self-correcting” behavior in the catalytic reactions, we have paid attention to the Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) ligand in the hope that the less electron-withdrawing power of the cyclopentadienyl group may enhance the stability of the C−C(carborane) bond toward nucleophilic attack, leading to the possible formation of [Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B9H10)]3- under deboronation conditions. On the other hand, it would allow us to make comparisons between the Me2Si- and Me2C-linked versatile ligands. Although all attempts to prepare a trianion of the type [Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B9H10)]3- suffered from the cleavage of the C−C(carborane) bond, our efforts have led to the isolation and structural characterization of the first example of a lanthanacarborane bearing a η 7-carboranyl ligand.

On the other hand, it would allow us to make comparisons between the Me2Si- and Me2C-linked versatile ligands. Although all attempts to prepare a trianion of the type [Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B9H10)]3- suffered from the cleavage of the C-C(carborane) bond, our efforts have led to the isolation and structural characterization of the first example of a lanthanacarborane bearing a η 7-carboranyl ligand.

elements.content: It has been well-documented that the alkali metals can reduce the neutral carborane C2B10H10R2 to the carborane dianion [nido-C2B10H10R2]2-, which is able to form the 13-vertex closo-metallacarboranes with the metal ions in a η 6 fashion. Such a metallacarborane can be further reduced by Na metal to form a 14-vertex closo-metallacarborane. For example, reaction of (η 6-C2B10H12)Co(η 5-C5H5) with Na/naphthalene, followed by treatment with C5H5Na and CoCl2, gave the 14-vertex closo-metallacarborane [(η 6:η 6-C2B10H12){Co(η 5-C5H5)}2] with the proposed geometry of a bicapped hexagonal antiprism. Although an X-ray confirmation of this species has not been reported, successful structural characterization of another 14-vertex closo-metallacarborane, [{η 6:η 6-(CH3)4C4B8H8}{Fe(η 5-C5H5)}2], has indicated that the bicapped-hexagonal-antiprism species is indeed the thermodynamically favored form. Nevertheless, the highest hapticity of carboranyl ligands in all of the known metallacarboranes described in the literature is 6, until our recent report on the unprecedented mixed-sandwich compound [{(η 7-C2B10H12)(η 6-C2B10H12)U}{K2(THF)5}]2, in which the U atom is η 7-bound to one of the C2B10H12 ligands. We have found new members of this novel class of metallacarboranes and report herein a detailed study on the syntheses, structural characterization, and reactivity of organolanthanide chlorides and carboranyl compounds as well as lanthanacarboranes containing a η 6- or η 7-carboranyl ligand. The mechanisms for the formation of these closo-lanthanacarboranes are also proposed. A portion of this work has been previously communicated.

elements.content: General Procedures. All experiments were performed under an atmosphere of dry dinitrogen, with the rigid exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk or cannula techniques, or in a glovebox. All organic solvents were freshly distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl immediately prior to use. Anhydrous LnCl3, LnI2(THF) x (Ln = Sm, Yb), 6,6-dimethylfulvene, and Li2C2B10H10 were prepared according to the literature methods. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received unless otherwise noted. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets prepared in the glovebox on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 Fourier transform spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer at 300.13 and 75.47 MHz, respectively. 11B NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Inova 400 spectrometer at 128.32 MHz. All chemical shifts are reported in δ units with reference to internal or external TMS (0.00 ppm) or with respect to the residual protons of the deuterated solvent for proton and carbon chemical shifts and to external BF3·OEt2 (0.00 ppm) for boron chemical shifts. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd, Brunel University, Middlesex, U.K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Procedures. All experiments were performed under an atmosphere of dry dinitrogen, with the rigid exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk or cannula techniques, or in a glovebox. All organic solvents were freshly distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl immediately prior to use. Anhydrous LnCl3, LnI2(THF) x  (Ln = Sm, Yb), 6,6-dimethylfulvene, and Li2C2B10H10  were prepared according to the literature methods. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received unless otherwise noted. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets prepared in the glovebox on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 Fourier transform spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer at 300.13 and 75.47 MHz, respectively. 11B NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Inova 400 spectrometer at 128.32 MHz. All chemical shifts are reported in δ units with reference to internal or external TMS (0.00 ppm) or with respect to the residual protons of the deuterated solvent for proton and carbon chemical shifts and to external BF3⋅OEt2 (0.00 ppm) for boron chemical shifts. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd, Brunel University, Middlesex, U.K.

elements.content: Preparation of Me 2 C(C 5 H 5 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 ) (I). This compound was prepared by using a modified literature method. To a solution of o-C2B10H12 (1.00 g, 6.90 mmol) in a dry toluene/diethyl ether (2:1) mixture at 0 °C was added a 1.60 M solution of n-BuLi in n-hexane (8.7 mL, 13.90 mmol) dropwise with stirring. The mixture was warmed to room temperature and stirred for 2 h. The solution was then cooled to 0 °C, and a solution of 6,6-dimethylfulvene (0.95 g, 9.00 mmol) in a toluene/diethyl ether (2:1) mixture was slowly added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 °C overnight and then quenched with 20 mL of a saturated NH4Cl aqueous solution at 0 °C, transferred to the separatory funnel, and diluted with 30 mL of diethyl ether. The organic layer was separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with Et2O (3 × 15 mL). The combined ether solutions were dried over anhydrous MgSO4 and concentrated to give a crude white solid, which was recrystallized from a EtOH solution to give a white crystalline solid (1.48 g, 85%). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 6.52 (m, 1H, Cp), 6.47 (m, 1H, Cp), 6.21 (m, 1H, Cp), 3.33 (s, 1H, CH of carboranyl), 3.00 (m, 2H, methylene of Cp), 1.52 (s, 6H, CMe 2). 11B{1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ −4.7 (1B), −5.2 (1B), −9.8 (2B), −12.3 (2B), −14.6 (4B).

elements.content: Preparation of [Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )]Na(THF) ( I- 1). To a suspension of NaH (0.18 g, 7.5 mmol) in 20 mL of THF was slowly added a THF solution (20 mL) of Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I; 1.40 g, 5.6 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The excess NaH was filtered off, and the clear colorless solution was then concentrated under vacuum to about 8 mL. After addition of n-hexane (20 mL), the white precipitate was collected, washed with n-hexane (10 mL × 2), and dried under vacuum, giving I-1 as a white solid (1.85 g, 96%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 6.40 (m, 2H, Cp), 6.30 (m, 2H, Cp), 3.65 (m, 4H, THF), 3.31 (s, 1H, CH of carboranyl), 1.70 (s, 6H, CMe 2), 1.62 (m, 4H, THF). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 103.4, 102.4 (C 5H4), 92.1, 67.3 (C 2B10H11), 67.2, 25.1 (OC 4H8), 41.5, 31.7 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −3.0 (2B), −5.0 (2B), −9.5 (3B), −13.9 (3B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3062 (m), 2985 (m), 2941 (m), 2879 (w), 2594 (vs), 1634 (w), 1456 (m), 1362 (m), 1261 (w), 1160 (w), 1075 (m), 1017 (s), 894 (m), 801 (m), 733 (m), 666 (m), 629 (w). Anal. Calcd for C10H21B10Na (I-1−THF):  C, 44.10; H, 7.77. Found:  C, 44.45; H, 7.83.

elements.content: Preparation of [Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 10 )]Li 2 (OEt 2 ) 2 ( I- 2). To a solution of Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I; 0.50 g, 2.0 mmol) in a dry diethyl ether/n-hexane (2:1, 15 mL) mixture was slowly added a 1.60 M solution of n-BuLi in n-hexane (2.5 mL, 4.0 mmol) at 0 °C with stirring, and the mixture was warmed to room temperature and stirred overnight. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with n-hexane (10 mL × 3), and then dried under vacuum to yield a white powder (0.73 g, 89%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 6.46 (m, 2H, Cp), 6.30 (m, 2H, Cp), 3.46 (q, J = 6.9 Hz, 8H, Et2O), 2.14 (s, 6H, CMe 2), 1.28 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 12H, Et2O). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 104.7, 103.0, 102.8 (C 5H4), 66.2, 15.9 ((CH3 CH2)2O), 42.4, 34.0 ((CH3)2 C); the carbon atoms of the cage were not observed. 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −5.2 (5B), −9.4 (5B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3061 (w), 2986 (m), 2882 (w), 2596 (vs), 1606 (w), 1495 (w), 1457 (m), 1361 (m), 1261 (w), 1158 (w), 1076 (s), 1022 (s), 897 (w), 802 (m), 735 (m), 668 (w), 626 (w), 493 (m). Anal. Calcd for C10H20B10Li2 (I-2−2OEt2):  C, 45.62; H, 8.04. Found:  C, 45.80; H, 8.30.

elements.content: Preparation of [Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )( nido -C 2 B 10 H 11 )]Na 3 (THF) 3 ( I -3). To a THF solution (15 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.18 g, 0.56 mmol) was added sodium metal (0.026 g, 1.13 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature until all the metal disappeared to give a colorless solution. This solution was concentrated to about 2 mL; n-hexane vapor diffusion gave a white solid (0.21 g, 70%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 6.88 (m, 2H, Cp), 6.40 (m, 2H, Cp), 3.64 (m, 12H, THF), 2.69 (s, 1H, CH of carboranyl), 2.27 (s, 6H, CMe 2), 1.60 (m, 12H, THF). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 102.4, 100.3 (C 5H4), 67.2, 25.1 (OC 4H8), 46.9 (C 2B10H11), 44.0, 32.6 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −2.3 (1B), −6.6 (2B), −11.0 (3B), −15.9 (2B), −24.8 (1B), −34.7 (1B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3060 (w), 2960 (vs), 2874 (s), 2463 (vs), 1455 (m), 1365 (w), 1258 (w), 1100 (w), 1040 (vs), 901 (m), 802 (m), 726 (s), 503 (w). Anal. Calcd for C14H29B10Na3O (I-3−2THF):  C, 43.06; H, 7.49. Found:  C, 43.32; H, 7.66.

elements.content: Attempted Preparation of [Me 3 NH][Me 2 C(C 5 H 5 )( nido -C 2 B 9 H 11 )]. To a mixture of Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I; 0.10 g, 0.40 mmol) and KOH (0.078 g, 1.4 mmol) was added distilled CH3OH (10 mL) with stirring at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was warmed to room temparature and then refluxed overnight. After removal of the solvent, water (3 mL) was added. The aqueous solution was neutralized with diluted HCl. Addition of aqueous Me3NHCl solution gave a white precipitate. The product was filtered off, washed with water, and dried under vacuum to give [Me3NH][nido-C2B9H12] as a white solid (0.071 g, 91%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ 3.09 (s, Me 3NH). 11B{1H} NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ −7.3 (2B), −13.2 (3B), −18.0 (2B), −29.4 (1B), −34.1 (1B).

elements.content: Other deboronation reagents such as n-Bu4NF/THF, KF/Al2O3/CH3CN, and pyrrolidine were also examined. 11B NMR was used to follow these reactions, and the results showed that only nido-C2B9H12 - was obtained and the C−C(carborane) bond was completely broken.

elements.content: Preparation of [ η 5 -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )]ErCl 2 (THF) 3 (1). A THF solution (20 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.27 g, 0.79 mmol) was slowly added to a suspension of ErCl3 (0.22 g, 0.80 mmol) in 10 mL of THF at room temperature. The mixture was then stirred overnight. The precipitate was filtered off, and the clear pink solution was concentrated under vacuum to about 15 mL; n-hexane vapor diffusion resulted in a pink crystalline solid (0.29 g, 52%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 17.4 (br s, 2H, Cp), 3.7 (s, 12H, THF), 1.6 (s, 12H, THF), 1.5 (s, 6H, CMe 2), −2.4 (br s, 2H, Cp). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 67.3, 25.3 (OC 4H8); other carbon atoms were not observed. 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −11.1 (2B), −13.3 (4B), −17.6 (4B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3060 (w), 2959 (s), 2879 (m), 2575 (vs), 1627 (w), 1460 (w), 1380 (w), 1261 (w), 1144 (w), 1024 (s), 913 (w), 794 (m), 499 (m). Anal. Calcd for C18H37B10Cl2ErO2 (1−THF):  C, 34.22; H, 5.90. Found:  C, 34.68; H, 5.55.

IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3057 (w), 2992 (w), 2947 (m), 2890 (w), 2564 (vs), 1613 (w), 1454 (m), 1379 (m), 1261 (w), 1144 (w), 1080 (s), 1039 (vs), 847 (s), 780 (s), 736 (w), 705 (w). Anal. IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3061 (m), 2970 (m), 2909 (w), 2580 (vs), 1607 (w), 1457 (m), 1382 (s), 1262 (w), 1139 (m), 1032 (s), 784 (s), 733 (w), 506 (m). Anal. elements.content: Preparation of [{ η 5 : σ -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 10 )} 2 Sm][Li(DME) 3 ] (6). To a suspension of SmCl3 (0.069 g, 0.27 mmol) in 10 mL of THF was slowly added a THF solution (10 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(Et2O)2 (I-2; 0.22 g, 0.54 mmol) at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then stirred overnight. After removal of the solvent under vacuum, the residue was extracted with toluene (15 mL × 2) to give a clear yellow solution. IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3081 (w), 2981 (m), 2930 (s), 2830 (m), 2554 (vs), 1602 (w), 1456 (m), 1369 (m), 1247 (m), 1186 (m), 1123 (s), 1085 (vs), 1033 (s), 867 (m), 833 (w), 773 (s), 696 (w). Anal. elements.content:
Reaction of YbCl3 with [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(Et2O)2 (I-2) in THF in a molar ratio of 1:1 also gave compound 7 in 50% yield.

Alternate Method. To a THF solution of YbI2(THF) x (8.6 mL, 0.41 mmol) was added a solution of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(Et2O)2 (I-2; 0.17 g, 0.41 mmol) in THF (10 mL). The mixture was then stirred at room temperature overnight to give a dark red solution, which was filtered into a THF solution (10 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.14 g, 0.41 mmol). The mixture was then refluxed for 3 days. The color of the solution gradually changed to red. This clear solution was then concentrated to about 5 mL. After addition of toluene (15 mL) and a few drops of DME, the resulting solution was allowed to stand at room temperature overnight, giving 7 as orange-yellow crystals (0.13 g, 33%).

elements.content: X-ray Structure Determination. All single crystals were immersed in Paratone-N oil and sealed under N2 in thin-walled glass capillaries. Data were collected at 293 K on an MSC/Rigaku RAXIS-IIC imaging plate using Mo Kα radiation from a Rigaku rotating-anode X-ray generator operating at 50 kV and 90 mA. An absorption correction was applied by correlation of symmetry-equivalent reflections using the ABSCOR program. All structures were solved by direct methods and subsequent Fourier difference techniques and refined anisotropically for all non-hydrogen atoms by full-matrix least-squares calculations on F 2 using the Siemens SHELXTL program package (PC version). Most of the carborane hydrogen atoms were located from different Fourier syntheses. All other hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed using the riding model. For noncentrosymmetric structures, the appropriate enantiomorph was chosen by refining Flack's parameter x toward 0. Two methylene groups (C11 and C21) of the two THF molecules in 10 are disordered over two sets of positions with 0.44:0.56 and 0.6:0.4 occupancies, respectively. Six methylene groups (C48, C51, C54, C57, C66, and C74) of the five THF molecules in 11 are disordered over two sets of positions with 0.5:0.5, 0.75:0.25, 0.5:0.5, 0.6:0.4, 0.6:0.4, and 0.6:0.4 occupancies, respectively. Crystal data and details of data collection and structure refinement are given in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Further details are included in the Supporting Information.

Ligand. Treatment of Li2C2B10H10 with 1.3 equiv of 6,6-dimethylfulvene in a mixed solvent of toluene and diethyl ether (2:1) at reflux temperature gave, after hydrolysis with a saturated NH4Cl aqueous solution and then recrystallization from a EtOH solution, compound Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I) as a white crystalline solid in 85% yield (Scheme ). The 1H NMR spectrum indicates that the CMe2 group in I bonds only to the sp2 carbon of the cyclopentadienyl ring. The 11B NMR spectrum exhibits a 1:1:2:2:4 splitting pattern which is similar to that of Me2C(C9H7)(C2B10H11)5 but differs from that of Me2Si(R)(C2B10H11) (R = t Bu, C5H5, C9H7 4).

Results and Discussion

 Ligand. Treatment of Li2C2B10H10 with 1.3 equiv of 6,6-dimethylfulvene in a mixed solvent of toluene and diethyl ether (2:1) at reflux temperature gave, after hydrolysis with a saturated NH4Cl aqueous solution and then recrystallization from a EtOH solution, compound Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I) as a white crystalline solid in 85% yield (Scheme ). The 1H NMR spectrum indicates that the CMe2 group in I bonds only to the sp2 carbon of the cyclopentadienyl ring. The 11B NMR spectrum exhibits a 1:1:2:2:4 splitting pattern which is similar to that of Me2C(C9H7)(C2B10H11)5 but differs from that of Me2Si(R)(C2B10H11) (R =  t  Bu, C5H5, C9H7 4).

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="om990941oh00001" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="om990941oh00001.eps"></graphic>
</fig>

Like the versatile ligands Me2C(C9H7)(C2B10H11), Me2Si(C5H5)(C2B10H11), and Me2Si(C9H7)(C2B10H11), I could be conveniently converted into the monoanion [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]- (I-1) and the dianion [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]2- (I-2) by treatment with excess NaH and 2 equiv of n-BuLi, respectively. The monoanion I-1 could be further converted into the trianion [Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B10H11)]3- (I-3) by reaction with 2 equiv of Na metal and into the pentaanion [Me2C(C5H4)(arachno-C2B10H11)]5- in the presence of LnCl3 and excess Na metal.
elements.clean_text: Like the versatile ligands Me2C(C9H7)(C2B10H11), Me2Si(C5H5)(C2B10H11), and Me2Si(C9H7)(C2B10H11), I could be conveniently converted into the monoanion [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]- (I-1) and the dianion [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]2- (I-2) by treatment with excess NaH and 2 equiv of n-BuLi, respectively. The monoanion I-1 could be further converted into the trianion [Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B10H11)]3- (I-3) by reaction with 2 equiv of Na metal and into the pentaanion [Me2C(C5H4)(arachno-C2B10H11)]5- in the presence of LnCl3 and excess Na metal.

elements.content: Unlike its Si analogues, treatment of I with 3 or more equiv of Na metal does not give the pure trianion I-3 on the basis of the 1H and 11B NMR spectra, presumably due to the lower acidity of the proton on the sp3 carbon of the cyclopentadiene. The acidity of the silyl-substituted cyclopentadiene in the Me2Si linked ligands is high, so that the acidic proton reacts vigorously with Na metal. In an alkyl-substituted cyclopentadiene such as I, Na metal may react simultaneously with both the carborane cage and cyclopentadiene or even react with the cage first to generate [Me2C(C5H5)(nido-C2B10H11)]2-, which then undergoes a proton-transfer reaction, affording [Me2C(C5H4)(μ-CH-nido-CB10H11)]2-. As a result, a mixture of products would be generated.

The acidity of the silyl-substituted cyclopentadiene in the Me2Si linked ligands is high, so that the acidic proton reacts vigorously with Na metal. In an alkyl-substituted cyclopentadiene such as I, Na metal may react simultaneously with both the carborane cage and cyclopentadiene or even react with the cage first to generate [Me2C(C5H5)(nido-C2B10H11)]2-, which then undergoes a proton-transfer reaction, affording [Me2C(C5H4)(μ-CH-nido-CB10H11)]2-. As a result, a mixture of products would be generated.

elements.content: Although the Me2C linkage is less susceptible to nucleophilic attack than the Me2Si linkage, the C−C( carborane) bond is surprisingly broken under various deboronation conditions such as KOH/MeOH, n-Bu4NF/THF, KF/Al2O3/CH3CN, and pyrrolidine, leading to the formation of nido-C2B9H12 - in almost quantitative yield, as indicated by 11B NMR. The reasons for the cleavage of the C−C(carborane) bond are not clear yet but must be related to the electron-withdrawing ability of the cyclopentadienyl ring. The above-mentioned transformations are summarized in Scheme .

Mono-, Bis-, and Tris-Ligated Organolanthanide Compounds. Treatment of anhydrous LnCl3 with 1, 2, or 3 equiv of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1) in THF gave mono-, bis-, or tris-ligated organolanthanide compounds in good yield, respectively (Scheme ). These compounds are soluble in polar organic solvents such as THF, DME, and pyridine and slightly soluble in toluene but insoluble in n-hexane. The mono- and bis-ligated compounds can lose the coordinated THF molecules under vacuum even at room temperature. All these compounds were characterized by various spectroscopic data and elemental analyses. The molecular structures of compounds 4 and 5 have been further confirmed by single-crystal X-ray analyses.

The solid-state structure of 4 is similar to that of [η 5- Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]2SmCl(THF)2. The Sm atom is η 5-bound to each of two cyclopentadienyl rings and σ-bound to one chlorine atom and two oxygen atoms from the coordinated THF molecules in a distorted-trigonal-bipyramidal geometry (Figure ). The average Sm−C, Sm−O, and Sm−Cl distances and related bond angles are all close to those in [η 5-Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]2SmCl(THF)2.

elements.content: Figure shows the solid-state structure of 5. It is the first tris-ligated organolanthanide compound containing three carborane cages to be reported. There are two crystallographically independent molecules in the unit cell with one solvated toluene molecule. The Sm atom is η 5-bound to each of three cyclopentadienyl rings in a trigonal-planar geometry, a typical structure for (C5R5)3Ln types of compounds. Two carborane cages are located on one side of this trigonal plane, and the other sits on the other side to minimize steric effects. The average Sm−C distance of 2.744(4) Å (or 2.721(6) Å) is comparable to that of 2.771(3) Å in 4.

elements.content: There are no direct interactions between the metal center and the B−H bonds of the carborane cages in both 4 and 5. However, the acidic C−H proton of the cage forms nonclassical hydrogen bonds with the cyclopentadienyl rings at an average distance of 2.578 Å for 4 and 2.586 Å (or 2.527 Å) for 5, respectively. These measured values fall in a range 2.184−2.765 Å normally observed for this type of bonding.

elements.content: [{ η 5 : σ -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 10 )} 2 Ln][Li(DME) 3 ]. Reaction of LnCl3 with 1 or 2 equiv of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(OEt2)2 (I-2) in THF, after recrystallization from a toluene/DME solution, afforded the ionic compounds [{η 5:σ-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)}2Ln][Li(DME)3] (Ln = Sm (6), Yb(7)). No [η 5:σ-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]LnCl(DME) x compound was isolated. Surprisingly, treatment of [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]SmCl2(THF)3 (2) with 1 equiv of I-2 also gave compound 6, presumably due to the ligand redistribution of the intermediate [η 5:σ-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Sm[η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)](μ-Cl)Li(THF) x . It is noteworthy that [η 5:σ-Me2Si(C9H7)(C2B10H10)]Er[η 5-Me2Si(C9H7)(C2B10H11)](μ-Cl)-Na(THF)3 is stable and structurally characterized. These results indicate that steric factors play a predominant role in stabilizing this type of compound. Scheme summarizes the above transformations.

Both compounds 6 and 7 were fully characterized by various spectroscopic and elemental analyses. Although they are isostructural, their 1H, 13C, and 11B NMR spectra are different from each other due to the paramagnetism of the central metal ions. Their IR spectra are quite similar.

Although they are isostructural, their 1H, 13C, and 11B NMR spectra are different from each other due to the paramagnetism of the central metal ions. Their IR spectra are quite similar.

elements.content: The solid-state structures of compounds 6 and 7 as derived from single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that they are isostructural and isomorphous. Figure shows their representative structure. Both of them consist of well-separated, alternating layers of the discrete tetrahedral anion [{η 5:σ-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)}2Ln]- and octahedral cation [Li(DME)3]+. In each anion, the Ln ion is η 5-bound to each of two cyclopentadienyl rings and σ-bound to each of two carbon atoms from two carborane cages in a distorted-tetrahedral arrangement, similar to that of [{η 5:σ-Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H10)}2Ln]-.

Both of them consist of well-separated, alternating layers of the discrete tetrahedral anion [{η 5:σ-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)}2Ln]- and octahedral cation [Li(DME)3]+. In each anion, the Ln ion is η 5-bound to each of two cyclopentadienyl rings and σ-bound to each of two carbon atoms from two carborane cages in a distorted-tetrahedral arrangement, similar to that of [{η 5:σ-Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H10)}2Ln]-.

elements.content: [ η 5 -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )] 2 Yb(THF) 2 and [ η 5 : η 6 -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )]Ln(THF) 2 . We have previously reported an unprecedented redox reaction between SmI2 and [Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]-, which led to the isolation of the mixed lanthanacarborane [η 5:η 6-Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Sm(THF)2. According to an earlier proposed reaction mechanism, other products should also be produced. We are very interested in this new reaction and have been trying hard to gain some insight into it. Treatment of SmI2(THF) x with 2 equiv of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1) in THF resulted in the isolation of both the mixed-sandwich samaracarborane [η 5:η 6-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Sm(THF)2 (9) and the tris-ligated organosamarium compound [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]3Sm (5) (Scheme ). The formation of these compounds can be rationalized by a reasonable mechanism, as shown in Scheme . Interaction of SmI2 with I-1 gives the first intermediate [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]2Sm(THF)2, followed by intramolecular and then intermolecular electron transfer to generate the anion {[η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)][η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B10H11)]SmIII(THF)2}- and cation {[η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]2Sm(THF)2}+; ligand redistribution affords the thermodynamically stable compounds 9 and 5.

The less reactive YbI2(THF) x reacted with 2 equiv of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1) in THF to give the organoytterbium(II) compound [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]2Yb(THF)2 (8), which supports the formation of the first intermediate shown in Scheme . Treatment of YbI2(THF) x with 1 equiv of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(OEt2)2 (I-2) followed by reaction with 1 equiv of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1) generated the unexpected cage C−H bond reduction product [{η 5:σ-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)}2Yb][Li(DME)3] (7) (Scheme ). This result differs significantly from that of the silicon analogue, in which only the organoytterbium(II) compound [η 5:σ-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H10)]Yb[η 5-Me2Si(C9H6)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF)3 4a was isolated and no redox reaction occurred. The above results indicate that the Me2C linkage can enhance the reducing ability of Yb(II) to reduce the cage C−H bond, but not enough to reduce the carborane cage, which allows the isolation of 8. This is one of a few examples showing that an organoytterbium(II) compound can reduce the C−H bond, since Yb(II) is usually considered to be a less powerful reducing agent.

elements.content: An alternate method to prepare the mixed-sandwich compound containing both η 5-cyclopentadienyl and η 6-carboranyl ligands is through the reaction of [Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B10H11)]Na3(THF)3 (I-3) with LnCl3 or the reduction of the compound [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]LnCl2(THF)3 by 2 equiv of Na metal. For example, treatment of [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]ErCl2(THF)3 (1) with 2 equiv of Na metal or reaction of ErCl3 with 1 equiv of [Me2C(C5H4)(nido-C2B10H11)]Na3(THF)3 (I-3) in THF at room temperature gave [η 5:η 6-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er(THF)2 (10) in good yield (Scheme ).

All compounds were fully characterized by various spectroscopic data and elemental analyses as well as X-ray diffraction studies. Their 1H, 13C, and 11B NMR spectra are different from each other. The IR spectra of 9 and 10 are quite similar, showing a unique doublet centered at about 2510 cm-1, typical of the ionic interaction between an anionic carborane ligand and a metal ion. The IR spectra of 5 and 8 exhibit a strong B−H absorption of the neutral carborane cage at about 2575 cm-1.

The IR spectra of 5 and 8 exhibit a strong B-H absorption of the neutral carborane cage at about 2575 cm-1.

elements.content: An X-ray analysis reveals that compound 8 crystallizes in space group P1̄, and there are two crystallographically independent molecules in the unit cell. Figure shows one of these two molecules. Each Yb2+ ion is η 5-bound to two cyclopentadienyl rings and coordinated to two THF molecules in a distorted-tetrahedral geometry, a typical structure for the Cp2YbII(L)2 compound. Two carborane cages stay away from each other to minimize the steric interactions, and there are no direct interactions between the Yb2+ ion and any one of the B−H bonds from the carborane cages. Similar to compounds 4, 5, and [η 5-Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]2Yb(THF)2, the nonclassical hydrogen bonds between the H atom on the carbon atom of the carborane cage and the cyclopentadienyl ring are observed in compound 8 at an average distance of 2.547 Å (or 2.605 Å), which is comparable to those reported in the literature. The average Yb−C distance of 2.725(6) Å (or 2.722(6) Å) is close to those normally observed in organoytterbium(II) compounds.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction studies indicate that compounds 9 and 10 are isostructural and isomorphous although they were prepared from two different methods. Figure shows their representative structure. The lanthanide ion is η 5-bound to the cyclopentadienyl ring, η 6-bound to the hexagonal C2B4 face of the carborane cage, and coordinated to two THF molecules in a distorted-tetrahedral arrangement. The average Sm−C(C5 ring) distance of 2.670(5) Å, Sm−cage atom distance of 2.807(5) Å, and Sm−O distance of 2.415(3) Å in 9 are close to the corresponding values in [η 5:η 6-Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Sm(THF)2 3b and are about 0.09 Å longer than those in 10, which can be compared to the 0.075 Å difference between Shannon's ionic radii of eight-coordinate Sm3+ and Er3+.

elements.content: The Na+ ions in 11 can be completely replaced by other ions. For example, treatment of 11 with 2 equiv of ErCl3 in THF at room temperature gave the novel tetranuclear metallacarborane cluster [{η 5:η 7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)}Er2(μ-Cl)(THF)3]2 (13) in 60% yield. It is noteworthy that the added Er3+ ions not only replace the Na+ ions but also compete with the existing Er3+ ions for the coordination sites, resulting in the formation of a new structural motif, which offers an opportunity to prepare heteronuclear metallacarboranes.

elements.content: Compounds 11−13 are extremely air- and moisture-sensitive but remain stable for months at room temperature under an inert atmosphere. They are soluble in polar organic solvents such as THF, DME, dioxane, and pyridine, sparingly soluble in toluene, and insoluble in n-hexane and decompose in CH2Cl2.

elements.content: They were characterized by various spectroscopic data and elemental analyses. The molecular structures of 11 and 13 have been confirmed by single-crystal X-ray analyses. It is interesting to note that the B−H absorption frequencies in the IR spectra shift to lower field on going from C2B10H11R via [nido-C2B10H11R]2- to [arachno-C2B10H11R]4-, for example, 2575 cm-1 for [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]ErCl2(THF)3 (1), 2512 cm-1 for [η 5:η 6-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er(THF)2 (10), and 2398 cm-1 for [{[η 5:η 7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er}2{Na4(THF)9}] n (11). These results imply that the IR data on B−H absorption may serve as a quick reference for the formation of carborane anions in some cases.

elements.content: An X-ray diffraction study reveals that 11 is a coordination polymer. Each asymmetrical unit contains two [η 5:η 7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er2- structural motifs that are connected by three Na atoms through several B−H−Na two-electron−three-center (2e−3c) bonds (Figure ). The asymmetrical units are then linked to each other via B−H−Er bonds to form an infinite polymeric chain. Each Er3+ ion is η 7-bound to [arachno-C2B10H11]4-, η 5-bound to cyclopentadienyl, and σ-bound to two B−H bonds from the neighboring [arachno-C2B10H11]4- unit in a distorted-tetrahedral arrangement. The novel 13-vertex closo-metallacarborane moiety in 11 is similar to that in [{(η 7-C2B10H12)(η 6-C2B10H12)U}{K2(THF)5}]2.

elements.content: The carborane ligand [arachno-C2B10H11]4- has a boatlike C2B5 bonding face in which the five B atoms are coplanar and the two C atoms are ca. 0.6 Å above this plane, resulting in an average Er−C(cage) distance being ca. 0.26 Å shorter than the average Er−B(cage) distance (Figure ). In comparison with the Er−C σ bond distances of 2.528(2) Å in [{η 5:σ-Me2Si(C5H4)(C2B10H10)}2Er][Li(THF)4], 2.44(2) Å in [(C5H5)2Er(μ-C⋮CBu t )]2, 2.458(19) Å in (C5H5)2Er(μ-Me)2Li(tmed), and 2.526(6) Å in [(C5H5)2Er(η 2-CHNBu t )]2, it is suggested that the Er−C(cage) bonds (average 2.410(6) Å) should be best described as σ bonds. The average Er−C(C5 ring) distance of 2.671(8) Å is longer than that of 2.602(5) Å in 10. The average Er−B(cage) distance of 2.671(7) Å is very close to that of 2.680(3) Å in 10. The average Er···B interatomic distance of 2.919(7) Å is significantly longer than that of 2.644(12) Å in [{(Me3Si)2C2B4H4}2Er]2[Li(TMEDA)2]2, presumably due to steric effects. The average Na(1)···B distance of 2.977(9) Å, Na(2)···B distance of 3.029(9) Å, and Na(4)···B distance of 3.015 Å are all comparable to those of 3.012(6) Å in [(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]4Sm2Na3 27 and 3.087(10) Å in [η 5-(Me3Si)2C2B4H5]Na(THF). As far as we are aware, 11 is the first lanthanacarborane containing a η 7-carboranyl ligand to be reported.

elements.content: The solid-state structure shows that 13 is a centrosymmetric tetranuclear metallacarborane cluster with two {[η 5:η 7-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Er2(μ-Cl)(THF)3} units that are connected by two sets of three B−H−Er 2e−3c bonds (Figure ). Each of the two Er(1) atoms is η 7-bound to [arachno-C2B10H11]4- and coordinated to two O atoms from THF molecules and one doubly bridging Cl atom in a distorted-tetrahedral geometry, a structure motif which differs from that of 11. Each of the other two Er(2) atoms is η 5-bound to the cyclopentadienyl ring and coordinated to one O atom from the THF molecule, one B−H bond from [arachno-C2B10H11]4-, one doubly bridging Cl atom, and three B−H bonds from the neighboring [arachno-C2B10H11]4- ligand in a distorted-pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry with the centroid of the cyclopentadienyl ring and H(9A) occupying the axial sites. The average Er(2)−C(C5 ring) distance of 2.597(4) Å, Er(1)−B(cage) distance of 2.655(7) Å, and Er···B interatomic distance of 2.787(4) Å are all shorter than the corresponding values in 11, perhaps due to steric reasons. It is noteworthy that the average Er(1)−C(cage) distance of 2.386(5) Å is shorter than that of 2.410(6) Å in 11, and it is the shortest Er−C bond distance ever reported in the literature, which again suggests that it is a σ bond.

elements.content: The ligand Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) can be converted into the monoanion, the dianion, and the trianion by treatment with suitable reagents, which lead to the isolation and structural characterization of mono-, bis-, and tris-ligated organolanthanide compounds, organolanthanide carboranyl compounds, and mixed-sandwich lanthanacarboranes, a chemistry which is similar to that of Me2Si(C5H5)(C2B10H11).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The ligand Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) can be converted into the monoanion, the dianion, and the trianion by treatment with suitable reagents, which lead to the isolation and structural characterization of mono-, bis-, and tris-ligated organolanthanide compounds, organolanthanide carboranyl compounds, and mixed-sandwich lanthanacarboranes, a chemistry which is similar to that of Me2Si(C5H5)(C2B10H11).

elements.content: The smaller Me2C linkage does not largely affect the coordination geometry of the central metal ions or overall molecular structures of the resulting compounds, but it can enhance the reactivity of the organoytterbium(II) compound, resulting in a cage C−H bond reduction product, a reactivity pattern which is different from that of the silicon analogue. Although this linkage is more chemically inert than the Me2Si linkage, it can still be attacked by OMe-, F-, and amine under deboronation conditions, affording nido-C2B9H12 -.
elements.clean_text: The smaller Me2C linkage does not largely affect the coordination geometry of the central metal ions or overall molecular structures of the resulting compounds, but it can enhance the reactivity of the organoytterbium(II) compound, resulting in a cage C-H bond reduction product, a reactivity pattern which is different from that of the silicon analogue. Although this linkage is more chemically inert than the Me2Si linkage, it can still be attacked by OMe-, F-, and amine under deboronation conditions, affording nido-C2B9H12 -.

elements.content: While the compound Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) cannot be directly converted into the pentaanion [Me2C(C5H4)(arachno-C2B10H11)]5-, its monoanion [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]- can accept four electrons from Na metal in the presence of LnCl3 to form a novel class of 13-vertex lanthanacarboranes bearing a η 7-carboranyl ligand. Another type of 13-vertex lanthanacarborane, [η 5:η 6-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Ln(THF)2, is suggested to be the intermediate in the above reactions. The large and highly electropositive lanthanide or actinide metal ions may play an important role in the formation of such a novel class of 13-vertex metallacarboranes.

Preparation of Me 2 C(C 5 H 5 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 ) (I). This compound was prepared by using a modified literature method. To a solution of o-C2B10H12 (1.00 g, 6.90 mmol) in a dry toluene/diethyl ether (2:1) mixture at 0 °C was added a 1.60 M solution of n-BuLi in n-hexane (8.7 mL, 13.90 mmol) dropwise with stirring. The mixture was warmed to room temperature and stirred for 2 h. The solution was then cooled to 0 °C, and a solution of 6,6-dimethylfulvene (0.95 g, 9.00 mmol) in a toluene/diethyl ether (2:1) mixture was slowly added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 °C overnight and then quenched with 20 mL of a saturated NH4Cl aqueous solution at 0 °C, transferred to the separatory funnel, and diluted with 30 mL of diethyl ether. The organic layer was separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with Et2O (3 × 15 mL). The combined ether solutions were dried over anhydrous MgSO4 and concentrated to give a crude white solid, which was recrystallized from a EtOH solution to give a white crystalline solid (1.48 g, 85%). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 6.52 (m, 1H, Cp), 6.47 (m, 1H, Cp), 6.21 (m, 1H, Cp), 3.33 (s, 1H, CH of carboranyl), 3.00 (m, 2H, methylene of Cp), 1.52 (s, 6H, CMe 2). 11B{1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ −4.7 (1B), −5.2 (1B), −9.8 (2B), −12.3 (2B), −14.6 (4B).

Preparation of [Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )]Na(THF) ( I- 1). To a suspension of NaH (0.18 g, 7.5 mmol) in 20 mL of THF was slowly added a THF solution (20 mL) of Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I; 1.40 g, 5.6 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The excess NaH was filtered off, and the clear colorless solution was then concentrated under vacuum to about 8 mL. After addition of n-hexane (20 mL), the white precipitate was collected, washed with n-hexane (10 mL × 2), and dried under vacuum, giving I-1 as a white solid (1.85 g, 96%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 6.40 (m, 2H, Cp), 6.30 (m, 2H, Cp), 3.65 (m, 4H, THF), 3.31 (s, 1H, CH of carboranyl), 1.70 (s, 6H, CMe 2), 1.62 (m, 4H, THF). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 103.4, 102.4 (C 5H4), 92.1, 67.3 (C 2B10H11), 67.2, 25.1 (OC 4H8), 41.5, 31.7 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −3.0 (2B), −5.0 (2B), −9.5 (3B), −13.9 (3B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3062 (m), 2985 (m), 2941 (m), 2879 (w), 2594 (vs), 1634 (w), 1456 (m), 1362 (m), 1261 (w), 1160 (w), 1075 (m), 1017 (s), 894 (m), 801 (m), 733 (m), 666 (m), 629 (w). Anal. Calcd for C10H21B10Na (I-1−THF):  C, 44.10; H, 7.77. Found:  C, 44.45; H, 7.83.

Preparation of [Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 10 )]Li 2 (OEt 2 ) 2 ( I- 2). To a solution of Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I; 0.50 g, 2.0 mmol) in a dry diethyl ether/n-hexane (2:1, 15 mL) mixture was slowly added a 1.60 M solution of n-BuLi in n-hexane (2.5 mL, 4.0 mmol) at 0 °C with stirring, and the mixture was warmed to room temperature and stirred overnight. The precipitate was filtered off, washed with n-hexane (10 mL × 3), and then dried under vacuum to yield a white powder (0.73 g, 89%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 6.46 (m, 2H, Cp), 6.30 (m, 2H, Cp), 3.46 (q, J = 6.9 Hz, 8H, Et2O), 2.14 (s, 6H, CMe 2), 1.28 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 12H, Et2O). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 104.7, 103.0, 102.8 (C 5H4), 66.2, 15.9 ((CH3 CH2)2O), 42.4, 34.0 ((CH3)2 C); the carbon atoms of the cage were not observed. 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −5.2 (5B), −9.4 (5B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3061 (w), 2986 (m), 2882 (w), 2596 (vs), 1606 (w), 1495 (w), 1457 (m), 1361 (m), 1261 (w), 1158 (w), 1076 (s), 1022 (s), 897 (w), 802 (m), 735 (m), 668 (w), 626 (w), 493 (m). Anal. Calcd for C10H20B10Li2 (I-2−2OEt2):  C, 45.62; H, 8.04. Found:  C, 45.80; H, 8.30.

Preparation of [Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )( nido -C 2 B 10 H 11 )]Na 3 (THF) 3 ( I -3). To a THF solution (15 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.18 g, 0.56 mmol) was added sodium metal (0.026 g, 1.13 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature until all the metal disappeared to give a colorless solution. This solution was concentrated to about 2 mL; n-hexane vapor diffusion gave a white solid (0.21 g, 70%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 6.88 (m, 2H, Cp), 6.40 (m, 2H, Cp), 3.64 (m, 12H, THF), 2.69 (s, 1H, CH of carboranyl), 2.27 (s, 6H, CMe 2), 1.60 (m, 12H, THF). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 102.4, 100.3 (C 5H4), 67.2, 25.1 (OC 4H8), 46.9 (C 2B10H11), 44.0, 32.6 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −2.3 (1B), −6.6 (2B), −11.0 (3B), −15.9 (2B), −24.8 (1B), −34.7 (1B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3060 (w), 2960 (vs), 2874 (s), 2463 (vs), 1455 (m), 1365 (w), 1258 (w), 1100 (w), 1040 (vs), 901 (m), 802 (m), 726 (s), 503 (w). Anal. Calcd for C14H29B10Na3O (I-3−2THF):  C, 43.06; H, 7.49. Found:  C, 43.32; H, 7.66.

Attempted Preparation of [Me 3 NH][Me 2 C(C 5 H 5 )( nido -C 2 B 9 H 11 )]. To a mixture of Me2C(C5H5)(C2B10H11) (I; 0.10 g, 0.40 mmol) and KOH (0.078 g, 1.4 mmol) was added distilled CH3OH (10 mL) with stirring at 0 °C. The reaction mixture was warmed to room temparature and then refluxed overnight. After removal of the solvent, water (3 mL) was added. The aqueous solution was neutralized with diluted HCl. Addition of aqueous Me3NHCl solution gave a white precipitate. The product was filtered off, washed with water, and dried under vacuum to give [Me3NH][nido-C2B9H12] as a white solid (0.071 g, 91%). 1H NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ 3.09 (s, Me 3NH). 11B{1H} NMR (acetone-d 6):  δ −7.3 (2B), −13.2 (3B), −18.0 (2B), −29.4 (1B), −34.1 (1B).

Preparation of [ η 5 -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )]ErCl 2 (THF) 3 (1). A THF solution (20 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.27 g, 0.79 mmol) was slowly added to a suspension of ErCl3 (0.22 g, 0.80 mmol) in 10 mL of THF at room temperature. The mixture was then stirred overnight. The precipitate was filtered off, and the clear pink solution was concentrated under vacuum to about 15 mL; n-hexane vapor diffusion resulted in a pink crystalline solid (0.29 g, 52%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 17.4 (br s, 2H, Cp), 3.7 (s, 12H, THF), 1.6 (s, 12H, THF), 1.5 (s, 6H, CMe 2), −2.4 (br s, 2H, Cp). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 67.3, 25.3 (OC 4H8); other carbon atoms were not observed. 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −11.1 (2B), −13.3 (4B), −17.6 (4B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3060 (w), 2959 (s), 2879 (m), 2575 (vs), 1627 (w), 1460 (w), 1380 (w), 1261 (w), 1144 (w), 1024 (s), 913 (w), 794 (m), 499 (m). Anal. Calcd for C18H37B10Cl2ErO2 (1−THF):  C, 34.22; H, 5.90. Found:  C, 34.68; H, 5.55.

Preparation of [ η 5 -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )]SmCl 2 (THF) 3 (2). To a suspension of SmCl3 (0.21 g, 0.82 mmol) in THF (20 mL) was slowly added a THF solution of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.27 g, 0.79 mmol) at room temperature, followed by procedures similar to those used in the synthesis of 1, affording 2 as a yellow crystalline solid (0.34 g, 62%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 10.5 (s, 2H, Cp), 7.65 (s, 2H, Cp), 3.74 (s, 1H, CH of carboranyl), 3.65 (m, 12H, THF), 1.61 (m, 12H, THF), 1.07(s, 6H, CMe 2). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 125.2, 112.1, 106.8 (C 5H4), 86.2, 64.4 (C 2B10H11), 67.1, 25.1 (OC 4H8), 42.8, 27.8 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −6.1 (3B), −11.0 (3B), −13.0 (2B), −15.2 (2B). IR (KBr, cm-1): ν 3061 (w), 2982 (m), 2957 (m), 2886 (w), 2575 (vs), 1631 (w), 1459 (w), 1373 (w), 1262 (w), 1143 (m), 1077 (s), 1043 (s), 1018 (s), 857 (m), 789 (s), 735 (w), 702 (w). Anal. Calcd for C14H29B10Cl2OSm (2−2THF):  C, 30.98; H, 5.39. Found:  C, 31.03; H, 5.74.

Preparation of [ η 5 -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )]NdCl 2 (DME) 2 (3). A solution of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.27 g, 0.79 mmol) in THF (20 mL) was slowly added to a suspension of NdCl3 (0.20 g, 0.80 mmol) in 20 mL of THF. The mixture was then stirred at room temperature overnight. After removal of the solvent, the residue was extracted with DME (10 mL × 2). The clear blue solution was concentrated to about 13 mL; n-hexane vapor diffusion resulted in a pale blue crystalline solid (0.19 g, 43%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 5.48 (br s, 2H, Cp), 3.56 (s, 8H, DME), 3.33 (s, 12H, DME), −1.92 (s, 6H, CMe 2), −6.06 (br s, 2H, Cp). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 202.5, 187.9, 169.3 (C 5H4), 81.5 (C 2B10H11), 71.8, 58.4 (O2 C 4H10), 41.2, 29.9 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −3.0 (2B), −8.2 (3B), −9.1 (2B), −11.1 (1B), −12.5 (2B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3057 (w), 2992 (w), 2947 (m), 2890 (w), 2564 (vs), 1613 (w), 1454 (m), 1379 (m), 1261 (w), 1144 (w), 1080 (s), 1039 (vs), 847 (s), 780 (s), 736 (w), 705 (w). Anal. Calcd for C14H31B10Cl2NdO2 (3−DME):  C, 30.32; H, 5.63. Found:  C, 29.86; H, 5.70.

Preparation of [ η 5 -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )] 2 SmCl(THF) 2 (4). To a suspension of SmCl3 (0.064 g, 0.25 mmol) in THF (10 mL) was slowly added a THF solution (15 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.17 g, 0.49 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The precipitate was filtered off, and the clear yellow solution was concentrated under vacuum to about 15 mL. 4 was isolated as yellow crystals after this solution stood at room temperature for days (0.087 g, 43%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 8.24 (s, 4H, Cp), 7.65 (s, 4H, Cp), 3.64 (m, 8H, THF), 3.55 (s, 2H, CH of carboranyl), 2.02 (s, 12H, CMe 2), 1.59 (m, 8H, THF). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 123.6, 110.9, 99.2 (C 5H4), 82.5, 63.4 (C 2B10H11), 67.1, 25.1 (OC 4H8), 44.3, 29.5 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −4.5 (6B), −9.8 (6B), −11.8 (4B), −14.0 (4B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3055 (m), 2983 (m), 2950 (m), 2883 (m), 2563 (vs), 1632 (w), 1461 (w), 1371 (m), 1265 (w), 1141 (m), 1072 (s), 1023 (s), 869 (s), 847 (s), 760 (s), 699 (m). Anal. Calcd for C24H50B20ClOSm (4−THF):  C, 38.09; H, 6.66. Found:  C, 38.56; H, 6.66.

Preparation of [ η 5 -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 11 )] 3 Sm · 0.5C 7 H 8 (5). A THF solution (10 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]Na(THF) (I-1; 0.13 g, 0.52 mmol) was slowly added to a suspension of SmCl3 (0.044 g, 0.17 mmol) in THF (5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. The precipitate was filtered off, and the clear yellow solution was then concentrated under vacuum to about 2 mL. After addition of toluene (15 mL), yellow crystals were obtained from this solution upon standing at room temperature for several days (0.091 g, 57%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 12.65 (s, 6H, Cp), 11.96 (s, 6H, Cp), 7.24 (m, 2.5H, C6 H 5CH3), 4.43 (s, 3H, CH of carboranyl), 1.42 (s, 1.5H, C6H5CH 3), 0.05 (s, 18H, CMe 2). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 129.0, 128.3, 125.4, 22.5 (C 6H5 CH3), 107.9, 103.1 (C 5H4), 77.7, 62.9 (C 2B10H11), 46.4, 28.5 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −3.9 (6B), −9.3 (9B), −11.5 (6B), −13.6 (9B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3061 (m), 2970 (m), 2909 (w), 2580 (vs), 1607 (w), 1457 (m), 1382 (s), 1262 (w), 1139 (m), 1032 (s), 784 (s), 733 (w), 506 (m). Anal. Calcd for C37H71B30Sm (5+0.5(toluene)):  C, 44.86; H, 7.22. Found:  C, 44.73; H, 7.16.

Preparation of [{ η 5 : σ -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 10 )} 2 Sm][Li(DME) 3 ] (6). To a suspension of SmCl3 (0.069 g, 0.27 mmol) in 10 mL of THF was slowly added a THF solution (10 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(Et2O)2 (I-2; 0.22 g, 0.54 mmol) at room temperature. The reaction mixture was then stirred overnight. After removal of the solvent under vacuum, the residue was extracted with toluene (15 mL × 2) to give a clear yellow solution. After addition of a few drops of DME, the solution was concentrated until some small crystals appeared on the wall of the flask, which was then allowed to stand at room temperature for 1 day, giving yellow crystals (0.15 g, 60%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 11.08 (s, 2H, Cp), 8.40 (s, 2H, Cp), 6.74 (s, 2H, Cp), 4.11 (s, 6H, CMe 2), 3.52 (s, 6H, CMe 2), 3.49 (s, 8H, DME), 3.26 (s, 12H, DME), −1.17 (s, 2H, Cp). 13C{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 151.3, 112.7, 108.2, 102.7, 101.4 (C 5H4), 87.8 (C 2B10H10), 71.4, 57.9 (O2 C 4H10), 51.0, 35.4 ((CH3)2 C). 11B{1H} NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −3.3 (2B), −4.7 (2B), −5.7 (4B), −8.3 (8B), −13.6 (4B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3081 (w), 2981 (m), 2930 (s), 2830 (m), 2554 (vs), 1602 (w), 1456 (m), 1369 (m), 1247 (m), 1186 (m), 1123 (s), 1085 (vs), 1033 (s), 867 (m), 833 (w), 773 (s), 696 (w). Anal. Calcd for C28H60B20LiO4Sm (6−DME):  C, 40.30; H, 7.25. Found:  C, 39.84; H, 7.33.

Reaction of SmCl3 with [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(Et2O)2 (I-2) in THF in a molar ratio of 1:1 also gave compound 6 in 51% yield.

Alternate Method. To a THF solution (15 mL) of [η 5-Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H11)]SmCl2(THF)3 (2; 0.27 g, 0.39 mmol) was added a THF solution (10 mL) of [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(Et2O)2 (I-2; 0.16 g, 0.40 mmol) dropwise. The mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight, followed by the procedures used above to give 6 as yellow crystals (0.098 g, 54% based on I-2).

Preparation of [{ η 5 : σ -Me 2 C(C 5 H 4 )(C 2 B 10 H 10 )} 2 Yb][Li(DME) 3 ] (7). This compound was prepared as orange-yellow crystals from YbCl3 (0.064 g, 0.23 mmol) and [Me2C(C5H4)(C2B10H10)]Li2(Et2O)2 (I-2; 0.19 g, 0.46 mmol) in 25 mL of THF using the procedures given above for 6. Preparation of Me  2  C(C  5  H  5  )(C  2  B  10  H  11  ) (I). This compound was prepared by using a modified literature method. To a solution of o-C2B10H12 (1.00 g, 6.90 mmol) in a dry toluene/diethyl ether (2:1) mixture at 0 °C was added a 1.60 M solution of n-BuLi in n-hexane (8.7 mL, 13.90 mmol) dropwise with stirring. The mixture was warmed to room temperature and stirred for 2 h. The solution was then cooled to 0 °C, and a solution of 6,6-dimethylfulvene (0.95 g, 9.00 mmol) in a toluene/diethyl ether (2:1) mixture was slowly added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 °C overnight and then quenched with 20 mL of a saturated NH4Cl aqueous solution at 0 °C, transferred to the separatory funnel, and diluted with 30 mL of diethyl ether. The organic layer was separated, and the aqueous layer was extracted with Et2O (3 × 15 mL). The combined ether solutions were dried over anhydrous MgSO4 and concentrated to give a crude white solid, which was recrystallized from a EtOH solution to give a white crystalline solid (1.48 g, 85%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 6.52 (m, 1H, Cp), 6.47 (m, 1H, Cp), 6.21 (m, 1H, Cp), 3.33 (s, 1H, CH of carboranyl), 3.00 (m, 2H, methylene of Cp), 1.52 (s, 6H, CMe 2). 11B{1H} NMR (CDCl3): δ -4.7 (1B), -5.2 (1B), -9.8 (2B), -12.3 (2B), -14.6 (4B).
